list_definition.definition: a type of small cart for carrying things etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She quickly filled the trolley with groceries.

list_definition.definition: (also tea-trolley, ( American) teacart) a small cart, usually consisting of two or three trays fixed on a frame, used for serving tea, food etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She brought the tea in on a trolley.

list_ex_of_english: Hence, there is a noncausal relation between the trolley turning away and the five being saved.
The extra push would change the impact on the one so that both person and trolley remain stationary.
If the one were not on the right-hand track, the trolley would rejoin the main track and hit the five from the front.
I suggested that there may be moral problems with turning the trolley only in the first case.
It apparently can matter whether the lesser evil is directly or indirectly caused, by, for example, turning the trolley.
It also creates a new problem: that of the trolley's looping around and hitting the five from behind.
Here the accidental trolley driver is on the scene and has exclusive control over where the trolley goes and what the consequences will be.
But if a required crane displacement is large enough, the trolley moves with the maximal possible velocity the most part of the movement duration.
